string-array.name: questions
string-array.item: What is physical health monitoring?
Why is physical health monitoring important for you?
What are the reasons for increased physical health problems in patients with schizophrenia?
Why should we do regular physical monitoring in patients with schizophrenia?

string-array.name: answers

item.p: Regular assessment and charting of few important physical parameters by the doctor at fixed intervals is called physical health monitoring. It includes few simple physical tests such as Blood pressure, pulse monitoring etc. performed by the doctor during your visit and some blood investigations. The interval of monitoring (e.g. monthly, weekly etc.) will be decided by your treating doctor and communicated to you. Physical health monitoring is an integral part in the management of patients with schizophrenia.

string-array.item: People with schizophrenia have increased rates of physical illness compared with the general population. Research has shown that the life expectancy of people with schizophrenia is reduced by 10 years as compared to general population.

There are several reasons for increased physical health problems:
 - Lack of monitoring and assessment of various parameters which can help in early detection of physical problems.
 - The health care needs of patients with mental illnesses are sometimes overlooked.
 - Patients with schizophrenia are often not able to communicate their physical problems to the doctor clearly.
 - Improper dietary habits
 - Lack of physical activity
 - Disturbances in lifestyle due to schizophrenia (e.g. poor self-care, disturbed sleep etc.)
 - Not following treatment regimen properly. (poor adherence)
 - Co-morbid substance use disorders (alcohol, tobacco, cannabis) worsens the physical health.
 - Side effects of medications

Early detection of physical problems leads to effective management It can prevent development of full-blown metabolic disorders such as Diabetes Mellitus, Hypertension, if corrected early. It motivates lifestyle modifications at the earliest which also helps in improvement of physical health Side effects of medicines are also detected early.

string-array.name: daily_routine_que
string-array.item: Why do you need to wake up on time?
Why do you need to brush your teeth daily?
Why do you need to take bath daily?
What is the importance of taking meals and on time?
Why do you need to take 8 hours of sleep and maintain regular sleep time?
What is the importance of walking for you?
Why do you need to engage in leisure activities daily?

string-array.name: daily_routine_ans
string-array.item: It is important to get up at right time in the morning because all activities of the day follow that.\n

Brushing your teeth at least twice a day is important to keep your teeth clean and healthy.

It prevents dental and gum diseases.

It also helps in maintaining a fresh breath that will help in enhancing your confidence.

Taking bath regularly is important for maintaining good health as it protects from infections.

Maintaining cleanliness is important for improving your appearance.

It helps in building self-confidence, physical and emotional well-being

Taking meals is an important daily activity. Food provides carbohydrates, proteins, fat, essential minerals, vitamins and fibres.

All types of food that you eat can be divided into four groups:

● Cereals, millets and pulses

● Vegetables and fruits

● Milk and milk products, egg, meat and fish

● Oils, oilseeds nuts

In a balanced diet, all types of food are in the desired quantities and proportions.

Three major meals and three minor meals containing all types of foods after every two hours helps in fulfilling daily nutritional requirement. It also helps in proper digestion.

Sleep gives rest to the body and mind.

Sleeping for 8 hours at night is essential for remaining healthy

IPoor sleep can result in poor attention and concentration, poor memory and irritability. It can affect physical health and may reduce immunity.

Regular sleep schedule helps in maintaining physical and mental health.

Walking is an important physical activity needed for good physical and mental health. 

It helps in prevention and control of obesity, joint pains, body-aches, diabetes, hypertension, heart disease and other chronic physical diseases. 

It improves mental well being, energy levels and quality of life.

In a day, walking for 30-45 minutes or taking 10,000 steps is important

Engaging in leisure activities is important activity in your daily routine.

By engaging in leisure activities you feel good, spend time effectively and prevent boredom. This helps in coping with stress, improving your quality of life, satisfaction and overall well-being.

Also, it acts as distraction from everyday worries.

string-array.name: iadl_que
string-array.item: What are Instrumental Activities of Daily Living?
Why are these important for you?
How will they improve your quality of life?
What do Instrumental Activities of Daily Life include?

string-array.name: iadl_ans
string-array.item: Instrumental Activities of Daily Living, often referred to as life skills, are actions that are important to being able to live independently. \n

It is seen that people with schizophrenia are often unable to carry out these activities adequately because of their symptoms. This leads to disturbance in their day-to-day living. Instrumental Activities of Daily Living are needed for improving your quality of life. \n

The instrumental activities are more advanced than basic day to day activities like bathing, brushing teeth etc. If you can carry them out, you will be more independent. You will be more confident about yourself. They can help determine the level of assistance required by you from your family members.
\n

IADLs include:
 1. Using public transportation 
 2. Using telephone 
 3. Meal Preparation 
 4. Laundry 
 5. Housekeeping

What is medication adherence?
What is medication adherence?
Why do you need medication adherence?
Why do you need medication adherence?
Why do you need medication adherence?

Why does poor medication adherence occur?
Why does poor medication adherence occur?

string-array.name: med_adh_ans
string-array.item: Taking your medication regularly as prescribed by your doctor\n
Taking your medication on time and at the correct dose and at correct intervals\n
Not skipping doses in between\n
Your illness is just like any chronic physical illness like diabetes, hypertension, etc.\n
Treatment of any chronic physical or mental illness requires long term medications which must be taken as suggested by your doctor\n
Adherence to your medication helps in improving symptoms\n
Reduction in your symptoms\n
Makes you feel better\n
Improves your functioning in day-to-day activities\n
Improves your ability to interact with friends and family members\n
Helps you to do your job\n
Reduces risk of relapse\n
Reduces the possibility of future hospitalization\n
Not taking medication on time\n
Not taking medication at specified intervals as prescribed by your doctor (e.g. three times a day/ two times a day etc)\n
Not taking correct dose (e.g. one tablet/half tablet)\n
No improvement in your symptoms\n
Worsening of symptoms with time\n
Relapse of symptoms which had improved in the past\n
Inability to do your daily activities\n
Disturbance in functioning\n
Inability to interact with friends and family members properly.\n
Arguments with family members\n
Not able to do your job/loss of job\n
Increased risk of hospitalization\n

It has been found that half of the patients suffering from schizophrenia may not take their medication regularly. Two types of causes are found to lead to poor medication adherence:


 1. Unintentional interruptions


 2. Intentional decision to miss/stop medications

1. Unintentional interruptions-- 

• Patient not fully informed about how to take medication

1. Unintentional interruptions-- 

• Forgot to take medication

1. Unintentional interruptions-- 

• Forgot to procure medication on time

1. Unintentional interruptions-- 

• Did not follow-up with doctor on time

2. Intentional decision to miss/stop medications-- 

• Inability to procure medicines. (e.g. due to lack of money to buy medicines or lack of information about where to procure them)

2. Intentional decision to miss/stop medications-- 

• Patients are bothered by side-effects

2. Intentional decision to miss/stop medications-- \n
\u2022 Myths and misconceptions\n
\n
MYTH 1:
Medications are addictive or habit-forming. They will become dependent on the medicines.\n
\n
FACT:
Most medications prescribed are not habit-forming.\n
However, a correct regimen has to be followed to increase or decrease the doses. This can be explained clearly by your treating doctor.\n
\n

2. Intentional decision to miss/stop medications-- \n
\u2022 Myths and misconceptions\n
\n
MYTH 2:
Medications are harmful in the long term\n
\n
FACT:
Medications prescribed are safe when taken as per the instructions of the doctor. They will help in improvement of symptoms.\n
Few side-effects may occur, but they can be taken care of by your doctor through various ways (dose adjustment, changing to a different medication etc)\n
\n

2. Intentional decision to miss/stop medications-- \n
\u2022 Myths and misconceptions\n
\n
MYTH 3:
My medicines are not helping in making me feel better\n
\n
FACT:
Medicines sometimes take longer to act and must be taken regularly for it to be fully effective. \n
Treatment for schizophrenia is long-term, and continued adherence to medicines help in improving symptoms and functional recovery.\n
\n

Understand the names of the medicines prescribed to you. If you have any doubts, ask your treating doctor before your consultation ends. (Tip: Request your doctor to write the names in CAPITAL LETTERS)\n
Understand clearly from your doctor about the correct dose and time of taking your medication. (Tip: Request for written instruction in simple language if required)\n
Ask your doctor about the common side-effects from the medications and what to do if they occur.\n

If you experience side-effects which you find problematic, visit your doctor as soon as possible instead of immediately stopping medications. There are often alternative options available to deal with side-effects.\n
Fix time for taking medications. (Tip: Pair with routine activities like taking meals)\n
You can encourage your relative to use simple devices like a clock or mobile to set alarms at time of taking medication\n

Make sure you have adequate stock of medication. Refill before your stock is completely over. (Tip: Every day after taking your medicines, make sure you have adequate stock for the next 2 to 3 days, if not, re-fill your stock.)\n
Come for regular follow-ups as advised by your doctor. In case of increase or decrease of medications, make sure you understand the instructions clearly.\n
Continue taking treatment in the same dosage if you are unable to come for follow up.\n
If you have any doubts or queries about your medications, feel free to ask your doctor regarding the same.\n
Do not stop the medication abruptly without consulting your doctor.\n

If you are unable to procure medicines due to any other reason (lack of funds, no medicine shops in your vicinity, lack of supply for a particular medicine etc.), make sure to discuss these issues with your treating doctor. It will help your doctor to look for alternative options.\n
Avoid harmful addictive substances (e.g. alcohol, cannabis)\n

Myths associated with Schizophrenia

string-array.name: psycho_edu_ans

item.li: Hello! Thanks for connecting with us. I will be sharing with you some basic information about Schizophrenia and how to support your family member who is suffering from Schizophrenia.

string-array.item: Schizophrenia is a chronic and severe mental disorder that affects how a person thinks, feels, and behaves. It interferes with an individual’s ability to perceive the world around them in the same way that the majority of people do. \n

Schizophrenia is also one of the poorly understood illnesses. There are various myths associated with Schizophrenia. Evidence gathered from studies and real narratives indicate that the following myths (though prevalent) are not true. \n

Truth: Schizophrenia is not rare; the lifetime risk of developing schizophrenia is widely accepted to be around 1 in 100. People living with schizophrenia don’t prefer to talk about it due to stigma. This makes the illness seem rare or non-existent.\n

Truth: Most people with schizophrenia are neither violent nor a danger to others. There may be a few situations where you might see your family member becoming agitated. For instance, if he/she is questioned or confronted directly about their experience of hallucinations or delusions. There are ways to deal with such situations that we will be talking in this module.\n

Truth: The modern science offers effective treatments for Schizophrenia. Long-term treatment may be required (as it is required in many other illnesses such as Diabetes, hypertension) and when treated properly, many people with schizophrenia are able to enjoy fulfilling, productive lives. \n
Truth: Medicines prescribed for schizophrenia are not addictive. If taken properly as prescribed by your doctor, they can be eventually tapered and stopped. \n

Truth: Treatment if started early can lead to decrease in symptoms and improvement in functioning of patients with schizophrenia. There are interventions that families can implement to help the person lead a more productive and normalized life.\n

The above misconceptions about Schizophrenia are baseless. It is important that we try to challenge these wrong perceptions whenever possible.\n
Further, you should talk openly with your psychiatrist about any query or concern you may have about Schizophrenia. This will help you to get more factual and scientific information. \n
It takes time to understand the real symptoms and signs of Schizophrenia that your family member may be experiencing. The common signs and symptoms of the illness are: \n

Hallucination: Person perceive things that don’t actually exist in the reality. These may include a person hearing voices, seeing things, or smelling things that others can’t hear or see or smell. \n
Please remember that the hallucinations appear real to the person experiencing it, and they it may be very confusing for the family members. Don’t engage in arguments/counter arguments about the content of hallucination with the patient.\n

Delusions: These are false beliefs that don’t change even when the person who holds them is presented with the new/contradicting ideas or facts. People who have delusions often also have problems concentrating, confused thinking, or the sense that their thoughts are blocked.
Don’t engage in the explanation of delusions or counter arguments with the patient. You don’t have to agree or support the delusional thinking of the person but at the same time don’t challenge them upfront. \n
Both hallucinations and delusions are symptoms of the illness and continued medication helps in alleviation of these symptoms.

Negative symptoms: Negative Symptoms are associated with disturbance and disruption in the normal emotions and behaviours. You may observe that the 

• person has lost interest in the day to day activities

• he is not reacting to any good/bad event like other people

• he is speaking little or not at all 

• seems to have a reduced ability to start or carry out even most basic activities (like brushing teeth, eating meals on time, going out of the house)

• is not interacting with other people or is interacting very little sporadically.

You can help the patient in alleviation of negative symptoms by taking small and consistent steps with them. Help the patient to prepare a schedule that involves doable and achievable activities of daily living. Integrate some pleasurable and social activities in their schedule. Appreciate their efforts (no matter how small or insignificant they might appear to you) taken in the direction of living a better life. \n

Cognitive symptoms: For some patients, the cognitive symptoms of schizophrenia can be severe and there may be noticeable changes in their memory or other aspects of thinking. Symptoms include trouble in focussing attention, poor ability to understand the information, difficulty in making decisions about seemingly simple issues, and trouble in implementing the instructions.ln
You can help the patient by simplifying the information for them. It also helps to break the task in smaller sub tasks and attaching simple and specific instruction with each sub task. \n

Other symptoms: 

• Changes in usual behaviour: preference to stay alone, getting irritated on trivial issues.

• Changes in sleep pattern: staying awake late in nights, preferring to spent most of the time on bed 

• Odd behaviours: smiling for no reason, muttering to self, maintaining too much of secrecy

• Decreased self-care: not interested in taking bath or maintaining hygiene

• The speech of the patients may be vague, disordered or muddled and may be hard to understand. It may appear meaningless due to lack of logical connection between sentences or phrases or words.

• Complaints about physical / bodily symptoms (such as bodyaches, headache etc )

• Feeling anxiety or ghabrahat:

• If the patient is complaining of feeling anxious or tensed in social situations (or even otherwise) don’t ignore it. Talk to the doctor about it during your follow up

Schizophrenia is an illness with primarily biological causes. 

Neurotransmitter Imbalance: The brain is made up of nerve cells, called neurons, and chemicals, called neurotransmitters. An imbalance of these neurotransmitter especially, dopamine, is thought to cause the symptoms of schizophrenia. The medications used for treatment of schizophrenia try to restore the imbalance of neurotransmitters.

Genetics: Scientists have long known that schizophrenia sometimes runs in families. Scientists believe that many different genes may increase the risk of schizophrenia, but that no single gene causes the disorder by itself. It is not yet possible to use genetic information to predict who will develop schizophrenia.\n
There are many people who have schizophrenia who don’t have a family member with the disorder and conversely, many people with one or more family members with the disorder who do not develop it themselves. \n

Environmental Factors: Scientists also think that interactions between genes and aspects of the individual’s environment are necessary for schizophrenia to develop. Environmental factors may involve: 

• Exposure to viruses 

• Malnutrition before birth

• Problems during birth

• Psychosocial factors

Their interaction differs from individual to individual and depends to one’s unique biological makeup and psychosocial environment.

There are numerous factors that lead to development of schizophrenia in an individual. These factors interact in multiple and complex ways so one can’t say what exactly might have caused the illness. It is important to acknowledge that there is no one single factor or person to be held responsible for the illness. \n

Pharmacological treatment: Antipsychotic medications are usually taken daily in pill or liquid form. Some antipsychotics are injections that are given once or twice a month. Some people have side effects when they start taking medications, but most side effects go away after a few days. Doctors and patients can work together to find the best medication or medication combination, and the right dose. \n

Psychosocial Treatments: These treatments involve learning of specific psychological and social skills by both the patient and their family member to address the everyday challenges of schizophrenia. \n
The current study is about development of mobile based psychosocial treatments that can be delivered from home. \n

The treatment plan of a patient is formulated by a case-to-case basis by a mental health professional after thorough assessment. For treatment to be successful, it is important to follow the treatment regimen diligently and follow-up regularly as and when asked by the doctor. \n

Caring for and supporting a loved one with schizophrenia can be hard. It can be difficult to know how to respond to someone who may be exhibiting behaviour that appears bizarre, may be unresponsive to your requests and is not ready to take initiative for anything. \n
Here are some things you can do to help your loved one: \n

Ensure the Treatment Adherence: 

• Encourage the patient to take the medication regularly. You can also assist them in taking the medicines on time by using simple reminder techniques, such as setting an alarm, maintaining a pills box etc 

• If the family member experiences discomfort or side-effects with any form of treatment, it is essential to discuss about it with the treating doctor instead of stopping treatment abruptly. Abrupt stoppage of medication can lead to sudden exacerbations in system, worsening the course and prognosis of the illness. 

• Keep up with the regular follow-ups with the treating psychiatrist. It serves two major purposes. First it helps to monitor medicinal compliance and second to adjust the therapeutic level of medications. 

• Keep a written note of any important incident or an observation you might have. This will help you to remember the key issues that you want to discuss with the doctor.

Know the early signs of relapse: \n
\u2022 Discuss the early warning signs of relapse with the treating psychiatrist. Develop a plan of action about what can be done as soon as you see the early signs of the relapse. \n

Learn to respond to the symptoms of illness 

Hallucinations/delusions 

• Remember that their beliefs or hallucinations seem very real to them. Don’t challenge them or indulge in arguments/counter arguments about them. 

• Express your disagreement with the content of hallucinations/delusions in a matter of fact manner. Don’t indulge in discussions or challenging the experience of the patient. 

• At the same time, delusions and hallucinations may be distressing for the patient. You can help the patient in easing off the distress. You can help them distract their mind or relax by indulging in some activity together.

Dangerous /inappropriate behaviour: 

• Be supportive of the patient without tolerating dangerous or inappropriate behaviour. 

• Express yourself using short, specific sentences that you don’t appreciate and accept the inappropriate behaviour. 

• Don’t use intimidating language or threaten the patient. 

• You can seek help of other family members to ensure your and patients safety.

• After the incident is over, discuss it with the patient and the doctor about how to avert such unacceptable behaviours in the future.

Communicating with the patient

Keep in mind the following simple principles while communicating with the person: 

• Talk in small, simple and direct sentences

• Focus on one topic at a time. Don’t give more than one instruction at a time or talk about multiple topics

• Remain consistent, with regards to your style of talking with the patient and your expectations from them

• Don’t use critical or intimidating language 

• Don’t pressurize the patient to do an activity 

• Remain supportive and appear available when you are with them 

• Use positive reinforcements or appreciations of them, whenever possible

• Don’t shy away from expressing your disapproval of the unacceptable/dangerous behaviour, without using harsh and threatening language.

Situations can arise with the patient that may require your direct intervention. Some of such situations can be when the patient stops taking the medicine, is not taking care of hygiene or is not maintaining their schedule. In such situations, following the problem solving techniques can help. Problem solving technique involves the following steps:

• Focus on the immediate problem behavior. Describe the problem specifically and in straightforward way (for instance instead of stating the problem as ‘ You are not maintaining hygiene’ , describe the exact problem behaviors like you are not bathing everyday / You haven’t brushed for 3 days) 

• Talk to the patient about the potential costs and benefits attached to this behavior 

• You can give your inputs too 

• Discuss with the patient about possible course of action, based on the cost and benefit analysis 

• Talk about the possible ways you can assist them in following up the course of action chosen by them

The problem solving skills are applicable in various situations. It is important that you start to practice these skills with the patient for problems that are concrete, current and in the situations where the patient has the capacity/ability to engage in the alternate behaviour (or to change their behaviour). \n
Remember to use the communication skills while problem solving with the patient. \n

For some people suffering from the symptoms of schizophrenia, things such as personal hygiene can become difficult to maintain. Teaching or encouraging participation in basic skills such as laundry, cooking, and other ways to care for a home and oneself, can help build self-esteem and motivation. \n

• Along with the patient, arrive at a list of daily activities that the patient needs to learn or practice. 

• Together mark the activities that the patient can do independently or those they might need assistance with. 

• The patient can define each task as a personal goal 

• Break each task into smaller and achievable subtasks 

• Patient can learn the new tasks by observing you and then doing them with assistance from you till they feel confident of doing them independently. 

• Reward and appreciate the achievements of personal goals and completion of activities. 

• If the patient is unable to complete a particular task, it is important to understand the reason for it and address the real problem (you can use the problem solving technique here) 

• Remain consistent in your communication, expectations and support to the patient

It is important that while you are helping your family member to live a normal life, you should neither be over involved and nor absent from their day to day life. Don’t complete the tasks for the patient. You may assist them in completion of these tasks. The purpose of assistance should be to help the patient become independent. \n
While you are at it, remember that the Rome was not built in a day. \n

Certain situations might invoke anxiety or fear. You might find that the patient is unable to perform even simple tasks that know well enough in places that are crowded. For instance, they may feel anxious in travelling by bus alone. Talk to the patient about their fear and anxiety. Provide reassurance. \n

You can follow the following steps of graded desensitization to help alleviate anxiety 

• Divide the task into small units of behavior or sub - tasks. For instance, the patient is feeling anxious to travel alone by metro to see the doctor. Together with the patient, divide it into specific tasks that the patient will have to take in order to travel alone. 

• Identify the least anxiety provoking behavior that they can do and start with it. 

For instance, patient can start to travel by metro along with a family member during the non-rush hours.

• Gradually, you can ask the patient to start performing the tasks independently. 

For instance, the patient may buy the ticket while you are standing a little away. 

• Once the patient has mastered performing one task move to another task. 

• As the patient starts to perform the task independently, you can let them feel more prepared. For instance, the patient can keep a route map or important phone numbers while travelling alone

Taking care of physical health is important for patients with schizophrenia and their family members.\n
There are some steps that you can take to ensure that you and your family members are leading a healthy life \n

Physical checkups: 

• Some common and vital tests may be important. Some of the tests that doctors often suggest for the patient include monitoring the weight, cholesterol blood pressure, blood sugar level and Hemoglobin. There might be some more tests that your doctor would ask you to get done.

• It is important that you get all the tests done immediately after doctor’s advise.

• The current app has a built in module for you to track the findings on these tests.

• Some of the medication for schizophrenia might lead to weight gain as a side effect. Weight gain can lead to more problems in future. It is important for you to get the weight checked periodically and enter the same in the app. The current app will calculate the BMI and give you your current BMI. The app will also show variation in weight over time. If there is any rapid weight change you observe, please talk about it with your doctor in next visit.

• Similarly, the app tracks findings for all other tests. You can observe variations in test findings and talk to your doctor in case there is anything that requires an immediate attention. 

• In case of health concern, talk to your doctor immediately. Don’t take Over the Counter medicine without consulting your doctor.

Staying active

• Patients with schizophrenia may not feel like doing much all day. This may be a part of illness. However, this is not good for their physical well-being.

• Patient should be encouraged to engage in some physical activity each day. The patient can decide what activity they want to take up to take care of their physical health. It can be walking, running, playing a physical sport or Exercising/Yoga.

• It is important that the chosen physical activity is done by the patient outdoors for it to be more beneficial. Family members or close relatives can participate in these physical activities along with the patient. 

• Physical activity has a positive impact not only on physical health but also the mental health. Regular exercising helps in release of chemicals in brain that are associated with pleasure.

Nutritious food taken at regular intervals is important for physical health and to avoid any health problems in the future. 

Some important tips to ensure healthy diet intake:

• Eat only home cooked food

• Eat at regular intervals and on time

• Avoid fat/ghee and oily food

• Restrict the intake of food high in sugar and salt

• Include vegetables and fruits in the diet everyday

• Your everyday diet should include pulses (if you are a vegetarian) and meat/eggs

• Dairy (milk, curd, buttermilk) and cereals (rice , pulses) should be taken. 

• Consume tea/coffee in moderation

• Abstain from smoking and taking alcohol

It is important that your entire family forms a habit of eating healthy food. Meals should be taken at the scheduled time and not erratically. 

All the family members should try to eat together whenever possible. 

Keep healthy foods (fruits, nuts, dairy) available at home. Don’t buy fried snacks/sweets as snacks too frequently

Healthy eating habits, regular physical exercises and addressing physical health concerns are important to ensure the physical well-being. This is important to be followed by all family members as a habit. \n

• Find out support systems available to you within family or in community. Some people find talking to fellow caregivers quite helpful. 

• Involve the family member with schizophrenia in everyday family discussions. Don’t exclude them from simple daily family activities.

• Ask them for their inputs in decision making process, whenever possible.

• As a primary family member, you also have the responsibility to protect your member from critical and harsh comments of society. Challenge the misconceptions, whenever possible.

• Don’t restrict yourself from social get together or having an active life beyond the care of your family member with schizophrenia. Involve those who you think can help in caring for schizophrenia. 

• Schizophrenia is a stigmatized illness. Not talking about it and not seeking help just increases the stigma and increases the feeling of isolation and loneliness. Try to be included in social forums or support groups wherein you can meet other people like you.

It’s may seem difficult to care for someone living with schizophrenia. It may get easier to take care of them as well as yourself if you start integrating some of the above skills in everyday interaction with the patient. \n

string-array.name: myDayQuestions
string-array.item: "How was your day?"
"How much effort and time did you spend in taking care of your needs?"

string-array.name: myDayAns1
string-array.item: "Good"
"OK"
"Not so good"

string-array.name: myDayAns2
string-array.item: "None at all"
"I tried to take out time but could not manage it"
"I spent some time and effort in taking care of my needs"
"I could take care of my needs well today"

resources.string:
•Please encourage your family member to take medicine on time. If needed, you can remind him/her to take medicine and also talk to him/ her about the benefits of taking medicine on time. 

•Please check daily whether your family member has taken the scheduled dose of medicines. If he/she has taken medicines for 7 days. 

•If there is any difficulty in ensuring medicine compliance, please talk to the doctor.

•Please encourage your family member to follow the daily routine activities independently. Following a structured routine will help bring positive changes in life. If needed, you can help him/her in performing some of these activities. 

•Please encourage him/her to engage in some physical activity every day. If needed, one activity can be divided into smaller parts. For instance, instead of walking for 30 minutes regularly a person can walk for 10 minutes 3 times a day. 

•Please check whether your family member is performing activities for daily routine. If he/she is performing for 7 days, at the end of a week, please put a star on his/her workbook.

\u2022There are activities that are important for self-reliance, such as shopping for basic needs, doing basic household activities, cooking own meals, washing own clothes, using public transport, using mobile phones etc. \n\n\u2022Try to engage in these activities regularly.

Disclaimer 
 

- I have understood the functioning of mobile app Saksham and I have agreed to use it for three months. After three months, I will return the smartphone to the research team at AIIMS.

 - I have understood that all the information entered by me and the images stored by me in the app will be kept confidential and secure.

 - I have understood that the information entered by me in the app and images stored by me in the app can be used for research purposes. My personal information or identifying information will never be used on any forum.

 - I have agreed that this app is NOT a replacement of the ongoing treatment at AIIMS. The app is in addition to the usual treatment services provided at AIIMS.

 - If there is an emergency situation, I will consult the treating doctor or physician.

 - I have had a chance to ask questions and get my doubts clarified related to the app and its functioning.

 - My participation in this study is entirely voluntary and I can quit the project at any time I want. Decision to not participate in this study will have no effect on the treatment at AIIMS.
I agree to take part in the above study.

PARTICIPANT INFORMED CONSENT FORM (PICF) FOR CAREGIVERS 


The nature and purpose of the study and its potential risks / benefits and expected duration of the study, and other relevant details of the study have been explained to me in detail. I understand that my participation is voluntary and that I am free to withdraw at any time, without giving any reason, without my ward’s medical care or legal right being affected.

The contents of the information sheet have been read carefully by me, and I have fully understood the contents. I confirm that I have had the opportunity to ask questions.

I understand that the information collected about me and my ward from our participation in this research and sections of any of his/her medical notes may be looked at by research team from AIIMS. I give permission to AIIMS research team to have access of my records.

If all your queries have been answered to your satisfaction and you are willing to participant in the study, please click on the button below.

PARTICIPANT INFORMATION SHEET (Caregivers)


Study Title: “Development of a mobile based intervention framework for difficult to treat patients with severe mental illnesses”.

 Investigator(s):

 Dr. R. K. Chadda
 Dr. Mamta Sood
 Dr. Pushpendra Singh

 Introduction: 

You and your ward are invited to take part in a research study. Before you decide whether or not to take part it is important for you to understand why the research is being carried out and what it involves. Please take the time to read the following information carefully and discuss it with others if you wish.
 (Part 1 tells you the purpose of the study and what will happen to you and your caregivers if he/she takes part.

 Part 2 gives you more detailed information about the conduct of the study)

Please ask us if there is anything that is not clear or if you would like more information. Take time to decide whether or not you wish to take part.


PART 1

 Who is organising and funding the study?


The funding for this study is provided by National Institute of Health Research (NIHR), UK and sponsored by University of Warwick, UK.

What is the study about?

This study would assess the feasibility and effectiveness of implementing a mobile based technology containing a suite of applications/modules as a psychosocial intervention for managing difficult to treat patients with severe mental illness (SMI). 

Do you and your ward have to take part?


Participation in this study is entirely voluntary and you are free to refuse to take part or withdraw from the study at any time (without having to give a reason) and without, in any way, affecting your future medical care or your relationship with medical staff looking after you. If you wish to participate in this study, we will ask you to sign a consent form to confirm that you have agreed to take part.

What will happen to me if I take part?


You and your ward would be given a mobile device, asked to follow up at fixed intervals and undergo assessments at Department of Psychiatry, AIIMS. The said mobile device will be provided free of charge. But you will have to return the device after study completion i.e. 3 months later. Before you start on this study, a doctor will check you’re eligibility for the study.

What are the possible disadvantages, side effects, risks, and/or discomforts of taking part in this study?


There are no particular risks anticipated in this study. This study will not involve any invasive procedure which might have side-effects.

What are the possible benefits of taking part in this study?


You will be monitored by the research team at AIIMS closely during the study. The study will not immediately benefit you, but if the results of the study are positive, it may help us in providing better psycho-education regarding illness and its management, improve quality of life by scheduling activities of daily living, and improve medication adherence.

Costs of participating / compensation for participation


Participation in this study will not result in any additional cost to you. Study equipments will be provided by the research team at AIIMs. Participants to the study will not receive any financial compensation.
\
What will happen when the study ends?


After the study ends, the clinical management of the participants will proceed as usual from our centre. The data obtained will be kept secure and confidential. The data will be analysed by the researchers and the findings will be discussed and shared in scientific forums in order to interpret it. The research will not immediately alter the regular treatments you currently receive.

Will my taking part be kept confidential?


Your personal data will be kept confidential. With your permission, identifiable information about you and data collected during the study will be held securely by AIIMS and under the control of the study investigators. All data collected in this study will be coded and stored on a computer system protected by a password only available to the researchers. No one outside the research team will have access to any identifiable information and all identifiable information and data will be kept securely. Your data will be archived securely for at least five years after the end of study as this is a legal requirement for clinical studies.

What will happen if I don’t want to carry on being part of the study?


Should you withdraw from the study, data collected prior to withdrawal will be kept, anonymously, for purposes of future medical research should you agree to that. However, if you wish, your data can be removed from our database. You simply need to inform the research staff what you prefer to happen in this instance. Participation in this study is entirely voluntary and refusal to participate will not affect you and your ward in any way including your usual care or any benefits.

What if there is a problem and right to raise concerns?


If you have any concerns about your participation in the study you have the right to raise your concern with a researcher involved in conducting the study or the doctor involved in your care.
Who should I contact if I wish to make a complaint?


If you have a complaint about your participation in the study, you should first talk to a researcher involved in the study. However you have the right to raise a formal complaint. You can make a complaint to a senior member of the research team or to the person below, who is a senior AIIMS official entirely independent of this study:

The Dean (Research),
 All India Institute of Medical Sciences
 Ansari Nagar 
 New Delhi

What will happen to the results of the study?


The results of the project will be shared and discussed with other researchers in scientific conferences (International and National). In the future the results will also be published in the form of research papers in scientific journals. We will provide a copy of the findings to the participants of the study, if you desire so. However, the results and findings will be available in journals and online scientific forums for your perusal.

Who has reviewed the study?


This study has been reviewed and given favourable opinion by the All India Institute of Medical Sciences Ethics Committee (IEC-745/29.12.2017, RP-19/2018).

What if I want more information about the study?


If you have any questions about any aspect of the study, or your participation in it, not answered by this participant information sheet, please contact:
 Dr. R.K Chadda (Telephone number – 011-26593245)
 Dr. Mamta Sood (Telephone number – 01126546634)
 Department of Psychiatry, All India Institute of Medical Sciences,
 Ansari Nagar, New Delhi -110029

If the information in Part 1 has interested you and you are considering participation, please read the additional information in Part 2 before making any decision.

 PART 2

 About the ‘Saksham’ App-
 ● You and your ward will be given a smartphone that has the app ‘Saksham’ uploaded on it. There are 4 modules in this app, which are medication adherence, daily routine, psycho-education and my day. Each module has information section that you can read to know more about the particular area that the module is about.

 ● You will also receive some notification for medication adherence and daily routine of your ward during the week. You can check the information and verify it in the module.

 ● In the module ‘My day’ you can enter some information about you.

 ● Investigator or one of the study team members will explain you how to fill up the information.

 ● The instructions on how to use this app will be given to you and your ward by the investigator, and it is also available in hard copy and soft copy form. If there are any queries or questions, you can ask the investigator anytime during the study.


Please read the following points carefully


• You and your ward are required to register with your email id, the first time you use the app. Your email id and password will not be shared with anybody.
 • Your name or any other identifying information will not be kept with any of your interactions within the app.
 • No one other than you, your doctor and the study investigators, will know whether you and your ward are using the app or not.
 • The information that you and your ward enter or the images taken by you in this app will be kept strictly confidential.
 • The app will collect some information from your phone activity, such as the details entered by you in specific app modules and images stored by you in the app.
 • Information related to when you opened the documents in this app to read them and when you read the messages shown by the app will be recorded.
 • We will not collect any of your location data or record any of your other phone activities beyond what we have described.
 • The data collected may be used for research purposes. Again, individual data or personal information (your name, date of birth, address, and phone activity beyond app usage) will not be used on any forum.
 • The notifications that you receive during the day are only for you. These will not be shared with anybody else. 
 • Your participation is entirely voluntary and you may quit the project at any time. All you have to do tell the study team at AIIMS that you no longer wish to participate and return the smart phone.
 • Your participation in this study is independent of your ward’s treatment at AIIMS. Your participation in the study will no way impact his/her treatment.
 • This app is NOT a replacement of your ward’s ongoing treatment at AIIMS. Please keep consulting his/her treating doctor or therapist.
 • If there is an emergency situation, please consult his/her treating doctor or physician.
 • We encourage you to think carefully and ask questions from the investigator to clarify your doubts. If there are any questions you may have, please ask the investigator now.


Thank you for taking the time to read this Participant Information Sheet.
No data present on the current day
